pp_necessities.description: A basic understanding of numbers as positions on a line, and of subtraction as measuring the distance between two points.
The ability to perform simple addition and subtraction, at least with multiples of 10.
Recognizing that numbers ending in 0 are "easier" to work with.

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The practical ability to add or subtract the same number from both the minuend and subtrahend. This is the core practice of the strategy.
The ability to identify a target number (usually a multiple of 10) and calculate the necessary adjustment to "slide" the subtrahend to that target.

pp_necessities.description: The ability to recite the number words in a fixed, repeatable order (e.g., "one, two, three...").
The ability to assign exactly one number word to each item being counted. In this case, the "items" are the counting acts themselves.
Understanding that the last number word said in a count represents the total number of items.
The ability to recognize the starting number.

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to begin at a given number and proceed through the number sequence, one step at a time.
The ability to keep track of how many steps have been taken and to stop when the required number of steps has been completed.

pp_necessities.description: The ability to perform basic addition, which might be used to solve the final, simplified problem (e.g., `30 + 5`).
A robust understanding of the base-10 system, including identifying the "next base" for a given number.
The ability to break a number into two or more parts (e.g., seeing 7 as 2 + 5).

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to calculate the difference between a number and the next multiple of 10 (e.g., for 28, the gap to 30 is 2).
The ability to decompose the second number in a way that is useful for the strategy (i.e., using the gap calculated in P4).
The ability to mentally re-group the numbers according to the associative principle (i.e., grouping the first number with the "gap" part of the second number).

lx_relations.explicit_principle: Associativity of addition can be used for strategic advantage.
lx_relations.explanation: RMB makes the associative property explicit to form convenient groups, while Counting On just implicitly relies on number system structure.

strategy_name: COBO (Counting On by Bases then Ones)

pp_necessities.description: Needed to perform the final step of adding the ones.
The ability to decompose a number into its base components (e.g., knowing 34 is 3 tens and 4 ones).
The ability to count in jumps of 10 from any number (e.g., 28, 38, 48...).

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to decompose the second number into bases and ones for the purpose of addition.
The practice of repeatedly adding the base value.
The ability to manage the two-stage process: first adding the bases, then adding the ones.

pp_necessities.description: Needed to perform the addition with the rounded number and the final adjustment.
Understanding of bases and how to round a number to the nearest base.
A basic intuition that if you change a number, you have to do something else to "make up for it".

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to identify an addend that is close to a base and calculate the amount needed to round it up.
The ability to perform the simplified addition.
The ability to remember the rounding amount and subtract it from the intermediate sum to get the final answer.

pp_necessities.description: Needed to add the chunks together.
The ability to break a number into parts (e.g., 34 is 30 and 4).
To guide the decomposition into meaningful (base-ten) chunks.

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to decompose an addend into chunks that are easy to work with (e.g., multiples of 10).
The practice of sequentially adding the chunks to the running total.
The ability to keep track of the intermediate sums and the remaining chunks to be added.

pp_necessities.description: Needed to subtract the individual chunks.
The ability to break the subtrahend into parts.
To guide the decomposition into meaningful chunks (e.g., 47 is 40 and 7).

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to decompose the subtrahend into chunks that are easy to subtract.
The practice of sequentially subtracting the chunks from the running total.
The ability to hold the intermediate results in memory as the subtraction proceeds.

pp_necessities.description: The core of the strategy is addition.
A conceptual understanding that subtraction and addition are inverse operations.
To make strategic jumps (e.g., knowing to jump to the next ten).

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to transform the subtraction problem into a "missing addend" problem.
The ability to plan and execute a series of jumps from S to M, often using multiples of 10.
The ability to keep a running total of the jumps made, which will be the final answer.

pp_necessities.description: Needed to perform the jumps.
A strong sense of the number line to navigate backwards.
To identify strategic "landing spots" (multiples of 10).

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to plan and execute a series of backward jumps from M with the goal of landing on S.
The ability to keep a running total of the jumps made.
To hold the current position on the number line and the accumulated difference simultaneously.

pp_necessities.description: The ability to reframe subtraction as a missing addend problem.
To understand the concept of jumping by tens.
The ability to add 10 to any number.
To handle the final "ones" jumps.

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to set up the problem as `S + ? = M`.
The practice of repeatedly adding 10 until the next jump would exceed the target (M).
The practice of counting on by ones to cover the remaining distance.
Keeping a running total of all the jumps (both base and ones) made.

strategy_name: Subtraction CBBO (Counting Back by Bases and Ones)

pp_necessities.description: The ability to decompose the subtrahend into its base components.
The ability to subtract 10 from any number.
The ability to perform simple subtraction of single-digit numbers.

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to decompose the subtrahend `S` into bases and ones for the purpose of subtraction.
The practice of repeatedly subtracting the base value from the minuend `M`.
The practice of subtracting the remaining ones from the intermediate result.
The ability to manage the two-stage process: first subtracting bases, then subtracting ones.

pp_necessities.description: To subtract the digits in each column.
The ability to write the problem vertically, aligning the place values correctly.
A basic understanding that a ten is also ten ones, a hundred is ten tens, etc.

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to follow the rigid, step-by-step procedure of the algorithm (right to left, borrow when needed).
The practical ability to decrement the higher place value and increment the lower one.
The practice of subtracting the digits within each column independently.

strategy_name: Conversion to Bases and Ones (CBO Multiplication)

pp_necessities.description: Needed to perform the simplified multiplication and the final adjustment.
To round one of the factors to a nearby base.
A conceptual understanding that multiplication distributes over addition/subtraction.

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to identify a factor that is close to a base and round it, keeping track of the difference `K`.
The ability to perform the simplified multiplication `A x B'`.
The ability to calculate the total adjustment needed (`A x K`).
The ability to correctly add or subtract the compensation from the intermediate product.

pp_necessities.description: To deal out one item at a time to each group.
To count the items in one of the final groups to determine the answer.
Understanding that the total number of items remains the same even as they are moved around.

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to set up `N` distinct groups.
The practice of distributing the `T` items one by one into the `N` groups, cycling through the groups.
The ability to recognize when the total `T` has been fully distributed.
The practice of counting the items in a single group to find the quotient.

pp_necessities.description: To recognize "friendly" numbers and calculate the partial quotients.
The ability to break a number into parts.
A conceptual understanding that division distributes over addition.
To sum the partial quotients.

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to decompose the dividend into numbers that are convenient multiples of the divisor. This is the key strategic element.
The practice of dividing each part of the decomposed dividend by the divisor.
The practice of adding the results of the partial divisions to get the final answer.

pp_necessities.description: To perform the repeated additions of the divisor `G`.
To count the number of iterations/groups.
A conceptual understanding that `E / G = ?` is equivalent to `? x G = E`.

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The ability to transform the division problem into a "how many groups of G are in E?" question.
The practice of repeatedly adding `G` while keeping a running total.
The ability to stop when the running total reaches `E` and to report the number of iterations as the quotient.

strategy_name: Conversion to Groups Other than Bases (CGOB Division)

pp_necessities.description: To break the dividend into its base-10 components.
To perform the core analysis of the base unit versus the divisor (e.g., `10 / 6`).
To correctly scale the base/divisor relationship across the magnitude of the dividend's components.
For multiplication and addition to consolidate remainders and sum the final partial quotients.

pp_sufficiencies_alg_elaboration.description: The core practice of analyzing the base unit (10) in terms of the divisor (`C`) to find a quotient (`q`) and remainder (`r`).
The ability to correctly scale the remainder `r` from the base analysis, add it to the original remainder from the dividend, and then divide that sum by the divisor.
The ability to identify all the partial quotients generated during this complex process and sum them to produce the final answer.
